main_text:
Life and Works
1. Life and Works

Bonaventure was born in Civita di Bagnoregio in central Italy, an
ancient city perched atop a constantly eroding volcanic butte. Though
Dante placed Bonaventure among the saints in his Paradiso
(Canto 12), and reports of Bonaventure’s holiness circulated in
the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, no official cult emerged
after his death and the papacy did not recognize him as a saint until
1482 (on Bonaventure’s canonization see Finucane 2011:
33–70). Had Bonaventure been canonized earlier, there might be
more information about his life to sift, as there is in the case of
his contemporary, Thomas Aquinas. What we can know about
Bonaventure’s early life comes from his own hagiographical work
on St. Francis of Assisi, the Legenda major and
minor, where he attests to being healed miraculously by St.
Francis:


when I was a boy, as I still vividly remember, I was snatched from the
jaws of death by his invocation and merits. (Legenda maior,
prol. 3, [FA:ED: Volume 2, 528]; cf. Legenda minor, lec. 8.
Texts of Bonaventure will be quoted in the Quaracchi edition,
1882–1902, unless a more recent edition
 exists[1])


One certain date, Bonaventure’s election as Minister General of
the Franciscans on 2 February 1257, permits a broad division of his
life into two clear periods: an academic and a pastoral
 period.[2]
 The academic period runs from c. 1235–1257. During those years,
Bonaventure studied and taught philosophy and theology at the
University of Paris and acquired the degree of Master in both
disciplines. The pastoral period runs from 1257–1274. During
that time, Bonaventure served as Minister General, relinquishing the
office on 19 May 1274 when Jerome of Ascoli was elected to replace
him. On 28 May 1273 Bonaventure became a Cardinal and was later
consecrated bishop of Albano (11 November 1273). Bonaventure died at
the second council of Lyon, 15 July 1274.

A fuller chronology of Bonaventure’s academic period can emerge
from sifting through various chronicles and from utilizing the data of
scholars’ evolving knowledge of the medieval University of Paris
and its degree programs. The general consensus remains that
Bonaventure left Bagnoregio for Paris in 1235 and studied philosophy
until 1243. A student’s guidebook from the faculty of arts at
Paris (c. 1240) provides a glimpse of Bonaventure’s training,
while his own works display his mastery of this discipline (anonymous,
Le “guide de l’étudiant”).
Bonaventure clearly knew and utilized the emerging corpus of Aristotle
and his Arabic commentators. The Parisian program in arts favored
logic and Bonaventure mastered and utilized this art, displaying his
mastery in discussion of metaphysical and theological issues. A text
like Peter of Spain’s Summaries of Logic
(13th century) displays the kind of logical training
Bonaventure probably received. Notably, scholars have not yet
identified any works from Bonaventure’s period as a student or
master of philosophy at Paris.

By 1244 Bonaventure had completed his degree in philosophy and was a
professed Franciscan friar. Bonaventure’s Letter to an
Unknown Master (commonly dated to the mid 1250s) gives some
insight into why he chose the Franciscans and displays his attitude to
philosophy at this
 time.[3]
 In one important passage of the Letter he writes:


And so, if the writings of the philosophers are sometimes of much
value in understanding truth and refuting errors, we are not departing
from the purity of faith if we at times study them, especially since
there are many questions of faith which cannot be settled without
recourse to them. (trans. Monti 1994: 53)


Bonaventure’s corpus shows that while he could be deeply
critical of positions he identified as philosophical errors
(especially in his last work, the Collationes in
Hexaëmeron), he consistently utilized philosophy and
philosophical authors in his theological and spiritual writings.

From 1243 to 1248, Bonaventure studied theology at Paris, surely
working closely with the Franciscan masters of this period: Alexander
of Hales (d. 1245), John of La Rochelle (d. 1245), Eudes Rigaud
(master c. 1245–1248), and then William of Middleton (master c.
1248–1254). At this point, Salimbene provides another important
date but one that requires some interpretation. Writing about 1280,
Salimbene states:


Br. John of Parma [Franciscan Minister General] gave the license to
Br. Bonaventure of Bagnoregio to read at Paris, which he had never yet
done because he was not yet installed in a Chair. He then read the
whole Gospel of St. Luke, a commentary that is very beautiful and
complete. This was in 1248. (Salimbene, Cronica
[Hodder-Egger: 209] and Hammond
 2009)[4]


Salimbene’s report cannot mean that John of Parma gave
Bonaventure a license in theology from the University of Paris, since
John had no authority to confer this degree. The license John granted
Bonaventure must therefore have been internal to the Order. Perhaps
John made Bonaventure a lector or granted him what scholars have
called the Franciscan’s second, internal chair at
 Paris.[5]
 In any case, the usual interpretation is that Bonaventure lectured on
the Bible cursorie as a “Bachelor of the Bible”,
between 1248 and 1250/51. Then, from c. 1252–53 he commented on
the Sentences, likely lecturing on the whole of the
Sentences in one year, in the typical order
 I–IV–II–III.[6]
 Once Master, he revised the Commentary (Commentaria in
Quattuor Libros Sententiarum), his major philosophical and
theological work. In 1253 he was a “formed Bachelor” of
Theology, performing the three duties of a Master: lecturing on the
Bible, engaging in disputations, and preaching. In 1253 the Masters
and students of the University of Paris went on strike, all but the
friars. The two Dominican masters and the Franciscan William of
Middleton continued to teach and refused to take an oath of loyalty to
the University. They were expelled from the “university of
masters”, an action defended by the University in a letter of 4
February (Chartularium Universitatis Parisiensis I, no. 230:
252–8, trans. Thorndike
 56–64).[7]
 Bonaventure received the licentia docendi by Easter 1254, in
the midst of this conflict. He assumed the Franciscan Chair in
theology immediately, but taught only at the Franciscan convent,
unrecognized by the University.

Bonaventure performed all three tasks of a Master of Theology from
1254–57. He revised his commentary on Luke and composed
commentaries on John and Ecclesiastes. He also held three sets of
disputed questions. The questions On the Knowledge of Christ
(De scientia Christi), which develop his illumination theory
of knowledge, may come from 1254. The questions, On the Mystery of
the Trinity (De mysterio Trinitatis), which elaborated
his view of God, certainly followed On the knowledge of
Christ, since they cite this disputation. Bonaventure also
disputed a third set of questions On Evangelical Perfection
(De perfectione evangelica). These questions defended the
friars’ way of life from the attacks of non-mendicant Masters
led by William of St. Amour in 1255 (Bougerol 1982; Traver 1995 and
1999). In October 1256, Pope Alexander IV ordered the secular Masters
at Paris to accept Bonaventure and the Dominican Thomas Aquinas in
their rightful places as Masters of Theology, but it was not until 12
August 1257 that they did so. Six months earlier Bonaventure had been
appointed Minister
 General.[8]
 In addition to the normal writings pertaining to his tasks as a
Master of Theology, Bonaventure produced numerous sermons during this
period. One text, related to the genre of sermons and known as On
Retracing the Arts to Theology (Opusculum de reductione
artium ad theologiam) may have originated as the second half of
Bonaventure’s inaugural sermon as a Master of Theology (Benson
2012). In 1257, while leaving the University and beginning his tenure
as Minister General, Bonaventure also managed to compose his
Breviloquium, a brief and popular synthesis of theology.

As noted above, Bonaventure’s “pastoral period” runs
from 1257–1274. Scholars can often pinpoint Bonaventure’s
activities at this time by utilizing his sermons and by studying
documents related to the Franciscan Order (Quinn 1974; Bourgerol (ed.)
1990). Bonaventure traveled extensively to visit Franciscan houses but
maintained Paris as his chief residence (Monti 2014). During this
period, Bonaventure’s writings reflected the needs of the Order,
but he did not cast aside his Parisian philosophical and theological
training. Bonaventure quickly set a firm direction for the Order in an
“encyclical letter” to all the friars on 23 April 1257,
which admonished them to recover the “somewhat tarnished”
luster of the Order (Monti 1994). Amid his other duties, Bonaventure
composed three extremely popular tracts between 1257 and 1260 for the
spiritual training of the friars: A Soliloquy about Four Mental
Exercises (Soliloquium de quatuor mentalibus
exercitiis), The Tree of Life (Lignum vitae),
and The Triple Way (De triplici via) (Coughlin 2006;
Cousins
 1978).[9]

Bonaventure’s most popular work today was also composed at this
time. For Francis’s feast day in October, 1259, Bonaventure
visited Mt. Alverna, the very place where Francis himself had received
a mystical vision of Christ “under the appearance” of
“a Seraph having six wings” and had “imprinted in
his flesh” the stigmata or wounds of Christ (Legenda
maior 13.3 [FA:ED: Volume 2, 632–633]). Here Bonaventure
conceived the idea for his Journey of the Mind to God
(Itinerarium mentis in Deum), a mental and spiritual journey
to God whose basic outline—though not its details—could be
understood by even the simplest friar (Armstrong 2020 is the most
recent English translation, offering extensive notes). The text
displays Bonaventure’s philosophical and theological training in
the service of articulating how to contemplate God. The journey
follows the route first charted by St. Augustine—from the
exterior world to the interior mind, and from the interior but
inferior human mind to the superior mind, namely, to God. Bonaventure
understood the six wings of the angelic Seraph Francis saw to stand
for six ways God can be approached. Among other things, the series of
six chapters also stood for Bonaventure as the six days of creation.
He therefore arranged his Journey into six chapters of mental
work followed by a seventh chapter on mystical rest. The two lower
wings of the Seraph symbolize seeing God through “footprints
(vestigia)”, signs in the sub-human world that point to
God, including signs in the physical universe itself (c. 1) and signs
found in the sensory life humans have in common with other animals (c.
2). The two middle wings of the Seraph symbolize seeing God in his
“image”, namely, in humans understood as bearing within
their intellectual nature special signs pointing to God. Here
Bonaventure distinguished signs of God found in the
“natural” exercise of the mind in theoretical knowledge
(c. 3) from those found in its exercise in the practical sphere
“reformed by grace” (c. 4). The two highest wings of the
Seraph symbolize seeing the light of God, first in the way reason sees
God as having one divine nature (c. 5) and then as faith sees God in
the Trinity of persons (c. 6). These three sets of twin
“steps” culminate in the “mental and mystical
transport” found in mystical experience (c. 7), the end of the
Journey. For each step, Bonaventure used material from
earlier writings; but the Journey, like all his later works,
is a synthesis the Minister General never had the leisure to expand.
In the Journey, he achieves a combination of scriptural
imagery, philosophic depth, mystical yearning, and a density more
meditative than demonstrative, as befitting the genre of the text. The
Journey, nevertheless, provides an appropriate outline for
looking at Bonaventure’s philosophy which will be pursued
below.

The General Chapter of 1260 held in Narbonne, France, the first where
Bonaventure presided, ratified his codification of the legal statutes
under which Franciscans lived, known as the “Constitutions of
Narbonne” and also asked him to write a definitive Life of
St. Francis, which he did in 1261. These two works set the Order
on a moderate course that lasted for centuries and led Franciscans to
revere Bonaventure as their “second founder”.

For most of the period from 1257 through 1266 Bonaventure trekked
through France and Italy by foot, as did all friars when they
traveled. In 1266 he returned to Paris, where his friars were under
attack both from conservatives in the Theology faculty and from
radicals in Arts. Bonaventure began giving a series of collations
(sermons offered in the morning and evening) which he considered a
sequence: Collations on the Ten Commandments (Collationes
de decem praeceptis), Lent of 1267; Collations on the Seven
Gifts of the Holy Spirit (Collationes de septem donis
Spiritus sancti), Lent of 1268; and Collations on the
Hexaëmeron (Collationes in Hexaëmeron) during
Easter-tide of 1273, a series that was never finished and is often
regarded as a masterpiece of medieval theology. Though the issues
covered in these collations range across nearly the whole of Christian
theology, they have come to be understood as Bonaventure at his most
polemical, since in them he attacks the three philosophical errors
that he believes are the most dangerous: the eternity of the world,
the necessity of fate, and that there is one intellect for all human
beings (On these collations see Ratzinger 1959 [1971] and
 2009).[10]
 Bonaventure thought all three of these errors undermined Christian
faith, the last of the three impacting the doctrineof salvation
 itself.[11]
 Notably, the series of collations are close in time to 10 December
1270, when certain Aristotelian positions were condemned by the Bishop
of Paris, Étienne Tempier.

In addition to these important collations, in 1269 Bonaventure again
defended mendicant life from the critiques of secular clergy in his
Apologia pauperum (Defense of the Mendicants). The
last period of Bonaventure’s life saw him rise to become one of
the most prominent men in Christendom. During the three-year Papal
vacancy, from 29 November 1268 to 1 September 1271, Bonaventure
preached an important sermon in Viterbo and was perhaps instrumental
in ending the vacancy. He is said to have been offered the papacy by
the electors and to have suggested Teobaldi Visconti instead. After
Teobaldi’s election as Pope Gregory X, he appointed Bonaventure
cardinal on 28 May 1273 (Franchi, 1981); Bartholomew of Pisa, the
earliest source for Bonaventure suggesting Teobaldo’s name,
wrote ca. 1385.). At the Second Council of Lyon, Bonaventure labored
for the reunification of eastern and western Churches, a major goal of
the Council which seemed to have been achieved when he suddenly fell
ill on 15 July 1274. The acts of the council then report:


at the hour of Matins died Br. Bonaventure of happy memory, Bishop of
Albano, who was a man eminent for his knowledge and eloquence
(homo eminentis scientie et eloquentie), a man outstanding
for his sanctity and acknowledged for the excellence of his life, both
religious and moral … Br. Peter of Tarantasia [also a Cardinal]
celebrated the funeral mass and preached on the theme “I am
saddened over you, my brother Jonathan”. There were many tears
and much weeping, for the Lord had given him such grace that the
hearts of all who saw him were seized with a desire for his love.
(Franchi 1965: 95; in Bougerol, 1988: 11)
